cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 170, Number 103 (Tuesday, June 18, 2024)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. WESTERMAN:H.R. 8790.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I of the U.S. ConstitutionThe single subject of this legislation is:To expedite under the National Environmental Policy Act of1969 and improve forest management activities on NationalForest System lands, on public lands under the jurisdictionof the Bureau of Land Management, and on Tribal lands toreturn resilience to overgrown, fire-prone forested lands.[Page H4115]

item.title: Treating Tribes and Counties as Good Neighbors Act

item.title: Treating Tribes and Counties as Good Neighbors Act

latestAction.text: Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry.

item.title: Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3334) to provide for the imposition of sanctions on members of the National Communist Party Congress of the People's Republic of China, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 8205) to amend the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to provide that Byrne grant funds may be used for public safety report systems, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 8790) to expedite under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 and improve forest management activities on National Forest System lands, on public lands under the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Land Management, and on Tribal lands to return resilience to overgrown, fire-prone forested lands, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the resolution (H. Res. 1469) ensuring accountability for key officials in the Biden-Harris administration responsible for decisionmaking and execution failures throughout the withdrawal from Afghanistan; and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

The Speaker designated the Honorable Scott Fitzgerald to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 1486 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 3334, H.R. 8205, H.R. 8790 and H. Res. 1469. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 3334 and H.R. 8790 under a structured rule and H.R. 8205 and H. Res. 1469 under a closed rule. The resolution provides for one hour of general debate on each measure with one motion to recommit on H.R. 3334, H.R. 8790, and H.R. 8205.

item.fullName: Del. Radewagen, Aumua Amata Coleman [R-AS-At Large]

item.name: Wilderness and natural areas, wildlife refuges, wild rivers, habitats

cdata.text:
Fix Our Forests Act

This bill establishes requirements for managing forests on federal land, including requirements concerning reducing wildfire threats, expediting the review of certain forest management projects, and implementing forest management projects and other activities.

Specifically, the bill (1) designates certain firesheds at high risk for wildfires as fireshed management areas; (2) directs the U.S. Forest Service and U.S. Geological Survey to jointly establish an interagency Fireshed Center that is responsible for duties related to assessing and predicting fire, including maintaining a fireshed registry on a publicly accessible website that provides interactive geospatial data on individual firesheds; and (3) makes other requirements related to reducing wildfire.

Next, the bill expedites the review of certain forest management projects under the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) of 1969 and exempts certain activities from NEPA review. It also establishes intra-agency strike teams to accelerate the review and any interagency consultation processes under NEPA, the Endangered Species Act of 1973, and the National Historic Preservation Act. It also limits consultation requirements concerning threatened and endangered species under the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974 and the Federal Land Management and Policy Act of 1976. Finally, it limits litigation involving fireshed management projects and limits remedies that courts may provide.

Additionally, the bill supports reducing community wildfire risks, carrying out forest restoration and stewardship activities, conducting biochar demonstration projects, and advancing technologies to address forest wildfires.

item.titleType: Short Titles from RFS (Referred to Senate) bill text
item.title: Fix Our Forests Act

item.titleType: Short Title(s) as Reported to House
item.title: Fix Our Forests Act

To expedite under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 and improve forest management activities on National Forest System lands, on public lands under the jurisdiction of the Bureau of Land Management, and on Tribal lands to return resilience to overgrown, fire-prone forested lands, and for other purposes.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 16 printed in Part D of House Report 118-705 to direct the Secretary of Agriculture to carry out a study on the impacts pine beetles have in the Northeastern region of the United States.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 15 printed in Part D of House Report 118-705 to require regional foresters to submit a plan for the sale of Christmas trees and firewood on federal lands.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 14 printed in Part D of House Report 118-705 to require regional foresters to submit a plan through the Collaborative Forest Landscape Restoration Program for the treatment and removal of trees killed by or infested with bark beetles in Western states.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 11 printed in Part D of House Report 118-705 to allow GNA revenue to be used for reconstruction, repair, and restoration of non-NFS roads necessary to implement GNA projects on federal lands, to allow GNA cooperators to construct new permanent roads on federal lands that is necessary to implement authorized restoration activities and approved by the federal agency through an Environmental Analysis or Categorical Exclusion decision, and to allow GNA cooperators to complete new permanent road construction to replace and decommission existing permanent road(s) that are adversely impacting forest, rangeland, or watershed health.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 7 printed in Part D of House Report 118-705 to direct the US Forest Service and the Department of the Interior to address reforestation and regeneration issues specific to the White Oak species through the White Oak Initiative and pilot projects.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 5 printed in Part D of House Report 118-705 to add thermal mid-wave infrared equipped low earth orbit satellites as a prioritized emerging technology for agencies to implement through public-private partnerships for wildfire mitigation and detection.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 4 printed in Part D of House Report 118-705 to clarify that special districts are eligible to participate in the wildfire-related programs authorized under the Healthy Forests Restoration Act of 2003. Also, the amendment clarifies that special districts are eligible to participate in the biochar research and development program established in Sec.301 of H.R.8790. Expands the Good Neighbor Authority to special districts.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 3 printed in Part D of House Report 118-705 to require the U.S. Forest Service to conduct an evaluation of the container aerial firefighting system (CAFFS) to assess the use of such a system to mitigate and suppress wildfires.

amendment.description: An amendment numbered 2 printed in Part D of House Report 118-705 to direct the United States Forest Service to expand the use of proactive, targeted animal grazing in fuels management programs to reduce wildfire risk.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
